awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectrometer for a  Cluster of Primarily Undergraduate Institutions in Rhode Island
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is jointly funded by the Chemical Instrumentation (CRIF) program, the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program. Professor Seann Mulcahy from Providence College and colleagues Christopher Laperle, Christopher Reid (Bryant University), Maria Carroll and Chin Hin Leung (Rhode Island College) are acquiring a 400 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer to replace an older one. In general, NMR spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. A typical use by a chemist is to analyze the mixture from a reaction to determine the products. This instrument is an integral element of teaching as well as research performed by undergraduate students at Providence College and neighboring Rhode Island College and Bryant College. It is also used in lecture and laboratory courses to prepare students for their careers. 

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. A variety of research projects are being investigated. One project involves studying the organic synthesis of nitrogen-containing heterocycles and the stereosymmetric preparation of beta-carboline atropisomers (stereoisomers arising because of hindered rotation about a single bond) for chemical catalysis and medicinal chemistry applications. Electrocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide is studied for possible remediation of the compounds. Another project is investigating solvation effects on prototypical iron pentacarbonyl-catalyzed photoassisted reactions to improve this procedure in organic synthesis. Functionalizable and degradable polymers for possible medicinal use and environmental applications are being investigated. Small molecule inhibitors of bacterial N-acetylglucosaminidases are being synthesized to foster understanding of cell wall metabolism.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program, was to acquire a new 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrometer, automated 24-sample changer, low temperature heat exchanger, and multinuclear probe in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Providence College (PC). This instrument was to replace an aging instrument to coincide with a major renovation of the science complex. The new instrument was used to support faculty-student collaborative research projects as part of a multi-institution cluster of primarily undergraduate institutions near Providence, Rhode Island, including at PC, Bryant University, and Rhode Island College. In addition, the NMR has supported the education and training missions of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at PC through its use in courses at all levels of the undergraduate curriculum.

The spectrometer was installed in June 2020, and subsequently moved to its permanent location in renovated space in January 2022. All of the co-PIs at Providence College have been trained on the use of the NMR, as well as their undergraduate research students. Progress has been made on each of the projects outlined in the proposal, including one publication from PI Mulcahy (PC), one from co-PI Carroll (PC), and two from Co-PI Reid (Bryant). These publications range in scope from organic and inorganic chemistry to microbiology and chemical education, highlighting the utility of the instrument in multiple disciplines. All of these publications underwent objective and positive peer review. Instrument use has increased significantly in Summer 2022, with more than 20 users in a 10-week summer undergraduate research program following restrictions due to COVID-19. The new instrument has increased the throughput of experimental samples due to use of the automation, allowing us to reach more than 200 students during the academic year. Data management procedures have been established and all work is being backed up on an external hard drive. Use of the NMR for educational purposes has begun, with walk-up use for undergraduate students as early as the sophomore year. Upper-level laboratory courses have also incorporated use of the NMR for T1 determination, compound characterization with different nuclei, and routine 2-D NMR. The education and training of talented undergraduate students was a significant piece of the project. We have 100% placement rate in our program into graduate school, preprofessional school, and industrial jobs upon completion of our program, with all of these students receiving hands-on training with the instrument.

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2022
Modified by: Seann Mulcahy
